$$._: Acoustic energy harvesting presents challenges due to low power density and the lack of efficient devices to convert it to electricity. Here, we developed a nanomesh acoustic energy harvester (NAEH) that harvests sound energy at a peak power density of 8.2 W/m

. The multilayered triboelectric nanomesh harvester with an overall thickness of 50 μm or less generates a high peak-peak open-circuit voltage of 396.9 V and a short-circuit current of 79.9 μA. In addition, a highly aligned polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) nanomesh layer generated piezoelectric charges when experiencing strain due to the application of sound pressure waves. The harvested sound energy from different sources at different pressure levels demonstrated the superiority of the NAEH in a wide pressure range. Systematic optimization of charging circuits and powering up a system comprising temperature and humidity sensors and a wireless transmission system with the harvested energy from a 108 dB sound source demonstrated an actual realization of the self-powered system.
Fabricated ultrathin (<50 μm), multilayered nanomesh acoustic energy harvester (NAEH)
Triboelectric and piezoelectric charge generation for high power density (∼8.2 W/m
Versatile sound energy harvesting: high performance in varied pressure levels
A self-powered system powers temperature, humidity sensors, and wireless transmission

Powering up a tremendous number of sensors from external power sources such as the battery is not economical or reliable. Harvesting of electricity from ambient environmental sources to realize a fully self-powered system has been a long-sought-after goal. However, among all clean sources of energy, harvesting acoustic energy is relatively more difficult mainly because of (1) its low incident power density and (2) the lack of efficient devices to convert acoustic energy into electricity. Here, we developed a nanomesh acoustic energy harvester (NAEH) that can capture energy from sound waves and convert it into electricity with high energy density. We optimized the charging circuits and used the harvested energy to power a system consisting of sensors and a wireless transmission system. This achievement demonstrates the potential for creating self-powered systems that can operate using energy harvested from sound.

Goni Nayeem et al. introduce the nanomesh acoustic energy harvester (NAEH), a significant breakthrough in sound energy harvesting. This thin, multilayered device efficiently captures sound waves and converts them into electricity with a peak power density of 8.2 W/m

. It outperforms existing technologies across different pressure levels, paving the way for self-powered systems using harvested sound energy to operate sensors and wireless transmission. This advancement holds promising implications for sustainable and autonomous energy solutions.
